Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Integrating Research and Education to Apply High-Rate GPS Into Natural Hazards Reduction
Award.AbstractNarration:
Global Positioning System (GPS) has grown to become one of the principal tools applicable to many disciplines, including geography, earth sciences, atmospheric sciences, environmental sciences, civil engineering, surveying, and others. GPS with a low-sampling rate (e.g., 30 second per sample) has been used by geoscientists for more than two decades to study plate motions. The new aspect of this project is to study high-rate GPS (e.g., 1 sample per second or higher), which is critical to conduct real-time monitoring and early-warning of natural hazards, such as earthquakes, tsunamis, and landslides. This project will foster the integration of education and research through conducting independent research, improving current geosciences curriculum, supporting and mentoring undergraduate and graduate research, and promoting faculty expertise development. The research component of this project will focus on improving precision of real-time high-rate GPS and promoting its applications in natural hazards monitoring and early-warning, while the educational component will focus on implementing GPS into earth science education at college as well as pre-college levels. Both components are based on a high-rate GPS network funded by a NSF Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) program. The high-rate GPS network includes six permanent GPS stations and four campaign GPS stations located in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. These permanent GPS stations are colocated with seismic stations operated by the Puerto Rico Seismic Network and Strong Motion Program and closely-spaced with sea level tide gauge stations operated by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). The integrated GPS-Seismic-TideGauge observation system has become a fundamental infrastructure for earthquake and tsunami research in Puerto Rico and its surrounding regions. The final goal of this project is to promote applications of real-time high-rate GPS in natural hazards reduction, and fuel our new generation (graduates, undergraduates, and K-12 students) with the cutting-edge GPS technology to prepare for a broad set of career paths. The specific objectives of the research are to (1) systematically evaluate the performance of high-rate (5-Hz, 10-Hz, or higher) GPS as a new seismometer, (2) develop new methods of improving precision of high-rate GPS, and (3) integrate real-time high-rate GPS into the earthquake monitoring and tsunami early-warning system operated by the Puerto Rico Seismic Network at the University of Puerto Rico-Mayaguez.

Real-time high-rate GPS technology is an integration of advanced GPS satellite, internet, real-time communication, solar power, computer, and visualization technologies. These new technologies will inspire students? interests in a spectrum of science, technology, engineering, and mathematic (STEM) disciplines, and attract more students to earth science majors, which will increase the diversity of earth science community. Education and outreach are the vital parts of this project. We will support two graduates, two undergraduates, and one high-school earth science teacher (in summer) each year. We will also develop a series of education and outreach activities related to the applications of GPS. They are expected to enhance public awareness of science and new technologies and increase the participation of underrepresented groups (Hispanics) in earth science research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported the Primary Investigator (PI) and his team for the purpose of exploring innovative applications of advanced Global Positioning System (GPS) technology in earthquake observation, tsunami early warning, real-time landslide morning and warning, and urban land subsidence monitoring. The PI was an assistant professor at the University of the Puerto Rico at Mayaguez during the first two years of this project (2009-2011). He and his team, in collaborating with other local agencies, established a dense GPS network (PRVINet) with 24 permanent GPS stations in the Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands region. The average GPS coverage along the Puerto Rico cost is one station every 20.0 km. The PRVI region has become one of the densest GPS coverage regions in U.S. The PRVINet has been integrated into the operation of the Puerto Rico Seismic Network for the purpose of enhancing its mission for regional earthquake monitoring and tsunami early-warning. The PI and his team also established a Stable Puerto Rico and Virgin Islands Reference Frame (PRVIRF14) based on continuous observations from the PRVINet. The PRVI GPS network and the local reference frame have become the fundamental research infrastructure in the Caribbean region for natural hazards study and education. The PI moved to the University of Houston in Texas in 2011. He and his team are investigating the land subsidence problem within the Houston metropolitan area. Funded by NSF and the University of Houston, the PI and his team have established a dense GPS network with 60 permanent GPS stations (HoustonNet) in the Houston metropolitan area for urban land subsidence and faulting study. The PI and his team also established a stable Houston reference frame (SHRF14), which is critical for precisely delineating long-term subsidence and faulting activities.

 

During the course of this project, the PI has been an advisor of one Ph.D. student and eight M.S. students that have graduated. There are currently six Ph.D. students and four M.S. students on track to graduate, The PI developed one GPS course (Geoscience Applications of GPS) at the University of Puerto Rico and two GPS courses (Satellite Positioning and GPS Geodesy, Geoscience Applications of GPS and LIDAR) at the University of Houston. The University of Puerto Rico and the University of Houston are Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSI). The PI has also been heavily involved in K-12 science education and public outreach activities organized by the Puerto Rico Seismic Network and the Houston GPS Network during the past six years. The GPS stations in Puerto Rico have become very attractive field sites for K-12 science education and public outreach. The Puerto Rico Seismic Network and the PI have developed several field routes and education materials for earthquake monitoring and tsunami early-warning. The majority of GPS stations that comprise the HoustonNet were installed on public school campuses. The PI and his team are collaborating with the school districts, elementary, junior high and high school science teachers, and educator specialists at UNAVCO to develop educational modules and public outreach materials in order to increase the participation of underrepresented groups (Hispanics) in earth science research and to enhance public awareness of science and new technologies.
